original_data.question: A 50-year-old woman is brought to the office by her daughter with a chief complaint of finger pain in her left hand. She is slightly confused and can’t remember when the pain started. Her daughter states that the pain has been present for approximately one month. She expresses concern that her mother has been progressively more confused during the past week. She reports that her mother also has had worsening nausea for several months. The patient’s vital signs are heart rate 92/min, respiratory rate 13/min, temperature 37.1°C (98.8°F), and blood pressure 120/86 mm Hg. Upon physical examination, the patient reports pain when the fingers of the left hand are palpated, and small palpable tumors are visible on the fingers. An X-ray image of the left-hand shows thin bones with brown tumors and osteolysis of the distal phalanges. What is the most likely cause for this patient’s condition?

model_response: The most likely cause for this patient’s condition is primary hyperparathyroidism. The brown tumors are collections of osteoclasts and reactive woven bone. The bone changes in primary hyperparathyroidism are caused by increased osteoclastic activity. The increased osteoclastic activity is caused by parathyroid hormone (PTH) stimulating the osteoblasts to form more osteoclasts. The increased osteoclastic activity leads to increased bone resorption and release of calcium into the blood. The increased calcium in the blood stimulates the kidneys to produce more calcitriol, which increases absorption of calcium from the intestine. The increased calcium in the blood also stimulates the renal tubules to excrete more phosphate. The net effect is that the blood calcium level is elevated, and the blood phosphate level is reduced. The elevated blood calcium level can cause calcification of blood vessels, particularly in the kidneys and the heart. This can lead to renal failure and cardiac failure. The elevated blood calcium level can also cause confusion and other central nervous system symptoms. The increased PTH also affects the kidneys, causing them to excrete more calcium in the urine. This leads to a reduction in blood calcium levels, which stimulates the parathyroid glands to produce more PTH. The increased PTH also causes the bones to release more calcium into the blood. The increased PTH also causes the kidneys to excrete more phosphate. The net effect is that the blood calcium level is elevated, and the blood phosphate level is reduced. The elevated blood calcium level can cause calcification of blood vessels, particularly in the kidneys and the heart. This can lead to renal failure and cardiac failure. The increased PTH also causes the kidneys to excrete more phosphate. The net effect is that the blood calcium level is elevated, and the blood phosphate level is reduced. This leads to a reduction in blood calcium levels, which stimulates the parathyroid glands to produce more PTH. The increased PTH also causes the bones to release more calcium into the blood. The increased PTH also causes the kidneys to excrete more phosphate. The net effect is that the blood calcium level is elevated, and the blood phosphate level is reduced. This leads to a reduction in blood calcium levels, which stimulates the parathyroid glands to produce more PTH. The increased PTH also causes the bones to release more calcium into the blood. The increased PTH also causes the kidneys to excrete more phosphate. The net effect is that the blood calcium level is elevated, and the blood phosphate level is reduced. This leads to a reduction in blood calcium levels, which stimulates the parathyroid glands to produce more PTH.

question_entities.definition: Human females as cultural, psychological, sociological, political, and economic entities.
A female human offspring.
The primary reason for a patient visit.
An unpleasant sensation characterized by physical discomfort (such as pricking, throbbing, or aching) localized to the finger. [UToronto:chum]
An unpleasant sensation induced by noxious stimuli which are detected by NERVE ENDINGS of NOCICEPTIVE NEURONS.
A female human offspring.
A constituent administrative district of a nation.
An unpleasant sensation induced by noxious stimuli which are detected by NERVE ENDINGS of NOCICEPTIVE NEURONS.
Every month.
The phenotypic manifestation of a gene or genes by the processes of GENETIC TRANSCRIPTION and GENETIC TRANSLATION.
Female parents, human or animal.
Any period of seven consecutive days.
Female parents, human or animal.

An unpleasant sensation in the stomach usually accompanied by the urge to vomit. Common causes are early pregnancy, sea and motion sickness, emotional stress, intense pain, food poisoning, and various enteroviruses.
One of the 12 divisions of a year as determined by a calendar. It corresponds to the unit of time of approximately to one cycle of the moon's phases, about 30 days or 4 weeks.
Individuals participating in the health care system for the purpose of receiving therapeutic, diagnostic, or preventive procedures.
Actions performed to measure temperature, pulse, respirations, and blood pressure
The number of times the HEART VENTRICLES contract per unit of time, usually per minute.
The rate of breathing (inhalation and exhalation) measured within in a unit time, usually expressed as breaths per minute.
The measure of the level of heat of a human or animal.
PRESSURE of the BLOOD on the ARTERIES and other BLOOD VESSELS.
A metric unit of length equal to one thousandth of a meter (10E-3 meter) or approximately 0.03937 inch.
Systematic and thorough inspection of the patient for physical signs of disease or abnormality.

An indication that the patient provides information about their vital signs, status, or subjective feelings. Some systems also consider information reported by the patient's family or guardian as patient-reported.
Four or five slender jointed digits in humans and primates, attached to each HAND.
Capable of being handled or touched or felt.
New abnormal growth of tissue. Malignant neoplasms show a greater degree of anaplasia and have the properties of invasion and metastasis, compared to benign neoplasms.
Four or five slender jointed digits in humans and primates, attached to each HAND.
Used with organs, regions, and diseases for x-ray examinations.

A left-handed double helix of DNA. Its name derives from its narrow zigzag structure that is the least twisted and thinnest form of DNA. Z-DNA forming regions within the GENOME may play an important role in GENE EXPRESSION REGULATION.
The structural organ comprised of specialized connective tissue that forms the skeletal components of the body.
A fibrous degeneration, cyst formation, and the presence of fibrous nodules in bone, usually due to HYPERPARATHYROIDISM.
Dissolution of bone that particularly involves the removal or loss of calcium.
Situated farthest from a point of attachment or origin, as of a limb or bone; or directed away from the midline of the body.
A bone in the fingers or toes.
A description of the physiological status of a patient.
